member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.CompatibilityMode
member.summary: Specifies limits to sheet size that correspond to specific versions of Microsoft Excel.

member.name: F:C1.WPF.Excel.CompatibilityMode.Excel2003
member.summary: Sheets may have up to 65,536 rows and 256 columns. Workbooks may have up to 4050 unique cell styles.

summary.para: Sheets may have up to 1,048,576 rows and 18,278 columns. Workbooks may have up to 65,536 unique cell styles.
Workbooks that exceed the Excel2003 limits must be saved in OpenXml format instead of XLS.
It may not be possible to open these workbooks with versions earlier than Excel 2007 (C1Excel will still open them correctly).
It may not be possible to open these workbooks with any version of Excel (C1Excel will still open them correctly).

summary.para: Represents an Excel workbook containing one or more worksheets.
Contains methods for loading and saving XLS files, and exposes a collection of objects that represent the individual worksheets.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class. The new workbook contains a single empty called "Sheet1".

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Sheets
member.summary: Gets a collection of objects that represent the worksheets in the .
member.remarks: The returned has methods for counting, enumerating, adding and removing sheets from the .

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.DefaultFont
member.summary: Gets or sets the default font object for the .

remarks.para: You can assign any font to any cell using objects. Cells that have no associated custom styles or have styles that do not define a custom font are displayed using the book's default font.
The property is initially set to 10 pt Arial.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.KeepFormulas
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should store formulas read from XLS/XLSX files and write them back when saving the file.

remarks.para: Setting this property to true allows you to load existing XLS/XLSX files, modify the values in some cells, and save the file preserving the formulas. This is the default setting.

Setting this property to false causes the component to remove the formulas in the book when it is loaded. Saving the file in this case will retain the last calculated values but will remove the formulas.
Assigning any value to a cell will clear the formula in the cell.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.OpaqueCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets a value specifying whether the component should copy non-main BIFF records as opaque when loading and saving XLS files.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Clear
member.summary: Clears the , restoring the initial state with a single called "Sheet1".
member.remarks: The method restores the object to its initial state, with a single empty sheet called "Sheet1" and the set to 10pt Arial.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Author
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the person, company, or application that created this .

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.ListSeparator
member.summary: Gets or sets a list separator that used for CSV-data, by default used the list separator in the Windows system.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.UseDefaultCsvEncoding
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should use the default encoding for CSV files.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.UseTempStorage
member.summary: Specifies whether the component should use temporary storage at saving to XLSX/XSLT files for minimization used memory.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.CalculationMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the formula calculation mode.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.NamedRanges
member.summary: Gets the collection of objects for the current workbook.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Palette
member.summary: Gets or sets color palette of this workbook.
member.remarks: The palette must be more 8 items (first 8 colors is standard pallete: Black, White, Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Magenta, Cyan).

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.ReferenceMode
member.summary: Gets or sets reference mode of this workbook.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.IsLoading
member.summary: Determines whether the workbook is currently loading.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.CompatibilityMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value determining the limits on sheet size and the number of styles allowed per workbook.

remarks.para: This property allows you to specify which version of Microsoft Excel you want your workbooks to be compatible with.
Excel2003 mode allows you to create sheets with up to 65,536 rows and 256 columns. Excel2007 mode allows you to create sheets with up to 1,048,576 rows and 18,278 columns.
Note that the XLS file format is limited by the Excel2003 limits. If you use the Excel2007 mode and create large sheets, save them into OpenXml files instead of XLS.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Load(System.String)
member.summary: Loads an Excel worksheet from a file.
member.param: Name of the file that contains the worksheet.

remarks.para: Component One Excel infers the file format automatically based on the file name extension. "XLSX" and "ZIP" files are loaded as OpenXml; all others are loaded as Biff8 files ("xls").
If the file doesn't exist, is locked, or is not a valid Excel file, an exception is thrown.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Load(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads an Excel worksheet from a file.
member.param: Name of the file that contains the worksheet.
True to load data into the sheets; False to read the sheet names only.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Load(System.String,C1.WPF.Excel.FileFormat)
member.summary: Loads an Excel worksheet from a file.
member.param: Name of the file that contains the worksheet.
value that specifies the file format.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Load(System.String,C1.WPF.Excel.FileFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads an Excel worksheet from a file.
member.param: Name of the file that contains the worksheet.
value that specifies the file format.
True to load data into the sheets; False to read the sheet names only.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.Save(System.String)
member.summary: Saves the worksheet to a file.
member.param: Name of the file to save.

remarks.para: The format used to save the file is automatically determined by the file name extension. "Xlsx" and "zip" files are saved as OpenXml; all others are saved as Biff8 files ("xls").
If the file can't be created, an exception is thrown. This typically indicates that the file is currently open by another application (such as Microsoft Excel).

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.C1XLBook.PixelsToTwips(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a pixel measurement into twips (1/20th of a point).
member.param: Measurement in screen pixels.
member.returns: Measurement in twips.

remarks.para: Excel stores measurements in twips (1/20th of a point), a resolution-independent unit. .NET controls, on the other hand, usually express measurements in pixels. This method provides an easy way to convert pixel measurements into twips using the current screen resolution.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLOpaqueShape
member.summary: Represents a shape that was inserted in the sheet using Excel and is preserved but not fully exposed by the component.

remarks.para: C1ExcelBook can load and save all types of shapes present in Excel sheets.
However, only image shapes are fully exposed (as objects).

All other object types are loaded and saved as XLOpaqueShape objects that cannot be modified. These include graphical elements (such as lines, rectangles, and arcs), VBA controls (such as edit boxes, and buttons), and comments.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPictureShape
member.summary: Represents an embedded in an .

remarks.para: XLPictureShape derives from the generic class to expose properties of images embedded in sheets. These properties include the actual as well as information on how it should be displayed, including , , and clipping information.

You can add images to cells simply by assigning objects directly to the property of objects. In this case, will create and initialize an XLPictureShape automatically. However, this method does not provide a lot of flexibility in terms of aligning, scaling, and clipping the image.

A more flexible option is to create an XLPictureShape object in code, using the constructor that takes alignment and scaling parameters, and then assign this XLPictureShape object to a cell's property.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLShape
member.summary: Represents a shape embedded in an .

remarks.para: Excel sheets may contain many types of embedded shapes, including images, graphical elements, controls, and comments.

The XLShape abstract class contains information that is common to all shape types, including the shape's location (, , , , ), the type of border drawn around the shape (, , ), the applied to the shape, and information.
The class derives from XLShape and is used to embed images in sheets.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell
member.summary: Represents individual cells in an and provides properties for getting and setting the cell , , and .

remarks.para: To create cells, use the indexer (Item property). If the cell already exists, the reference will be returned as usual. If not, the sheet will create the cell (as well as rows and columns if necessary) and will return a reference to the new cell.
Because it creates cells automatically, the indexer is especially useful when creating and populating sheets.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell.Clone
member.summary: Creates a copy of the current cell, including the value.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of the current instance.
member.remarks: The formula of the cell is cloned only as part of a row, a worksheet or a workbook.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value stored in the cell.

remarks.para: The value may contain strings, numeric, Boolean, DateTime, or null objects. Other types of objects cannot be saved in Excel files.

DateTime values are internally converted into doubles, and stored in the sheet as such. The only way to tell the difference between a DateTime value and a double in Excel is by way of the format associated with the cell ( property).

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell.Style
member.summary: Gets or sets the object associated with the cell.

remarks.para: The appearance of each cell is defined by one or more XLStyle objects.
When displaying a cell, Excel combines the row, column, and cell styles and merges the style elements defined in each one in order to determine how the cell should be displayed.

The precedence of the styles is: (1) cell, (2) row, (3) column, (4) default style. For example, if a cell style defines the font and background color, those will be applied regardless of the settings in the row and column styles. If the row style defines an alignment, that will be applied regardless of the column style, and so on.
The cell style may be null, in which case the cell is displayed using the other styles available or the default book style if no others are available.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell.Hyperlink
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that specifies an action to take when the cell is clicked.

remarks.para: Hyperlinks may contain URLs that when clicked open a browser window and navigate to the specified site (for example, "http://www.grapecity.com"). They may also contain references to files that are launched by the application associated with the file type (for example, "readme.doc"). Finally, hyperlinks can be used to send e-mails (for example, "mailto:joe@foo.com").
Each cell may contain a hyperlink and a value. However, if you assign a hyperlink to a cell that has no value ( == null), then the hyperlink text is automatically assigned to the cell value as well.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLCell.Formula
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that specifies a formula of the cell.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings
member.summary: Provides options and settings for printing objects.

remarks.para: The settings are applied to each sheet and are accessible through the sheet's property.
Note that does not provide any printing services. The settings are used when printing the sheet from Excel.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of the current instance.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of the current instance.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings.Header
member.summary: Gets or sets the string to be displayed as a page header when the sheet is printed.
member.remarks:
The header string may contain special commands, i.e. placeholders for the page number, current date, or text formatting attributes. Most of these fields are represented by single letters with a leading ampersand ("&").
The page header is divided into 3 sections: left, center, and right. Each section is introduced by a special command ("&L", "&C", and "&R"). All text and all commands following are part of the selected section.
The following commands are available:
&L Start of the left section
&C Start of the centered section
&R Start of the right section
&P Current page number
&N Page count
&D Current date
&T Current time
&A Sheet name
&F File name without path
&Z File path without file name
&G Picture (file name)
&B Bold toggle
&I Italic toggle
&U Underline toggle
&E Double underline toggle
&S Strikeout toggle
&X Superscript toggle
&Y Subscript toggle
&"[FontName]" Set new font
&"[FontName,FontStyle]" Set new font with specified style. The style is in most cases "Regular", "Bold", "Italic", or "Bold Italic". &[fontheight] Set font height in points.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings.Footer
member.summary: Gets or sets the string to be displayed as a page footer when the sheet is printed.
member.remarks: The footer string has the same structure and embedded commands as the header string. See the property for details.

member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling factor (in percent) to use when printing the sheet.
member.remarks: Setting the property automatically sets the property to false, causing C1Excel to use the selected scaling factor and to ignore the value of the and properties.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLPrintSettings.AutoScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling mode used for printed output.

remarks.para: If is set to true, then the printed sheet will be automatically scaled to fit the number of pages specified by the and properties.
If is set to false, then the printed sheet will be scaled according to the value of the property.

member.summary: Creates a copy of this sheet.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLSheet.DefaultRowHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the default row height for the sheet (in twips).

remarks.para: You can set the height of individual rows using the class. Any rows that do not have a custom height assigned to them will be displayed using the sheet's .
The property is expressed in twips (1/20th of a point), rather than pixels. This allows sheets to maintain their aspect regardless of the resolution of the display.
To convert twips into pixels, use the method in . To convert pixels into twips, use the method.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLSheet.DefaultColumnWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the default column width for the sheet (in twips).

remarks.para: You can set the width of individual rows using the class. Any columns that do not have a custom width assigned to them will be displayed using the sheet's .
The property is expressed in twips (1/20th of a point), rather than pixels. This allows sheets to maintain their aspect regardless of the resolution of the display.
To convert twips into pixels, use the method in . To convert pixels into twips, use the method.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLSheet.Item(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the cell at a specified position on the sheet, creating a new cell if necessary.

remarks.para: If the specified cell doesn't exist when the indexer is invoked, the sheet will be expanded and a new cell will be created, then returned. This makes it easy to create and populate sheets.
If you want to determine whether a specific cell has been defined, use the method instead.
The indexer is generally more useful when creating and populating sheets. The method is more useful when loading existing sheets.

member.name: M:C1.WPF.Excel.XLSheet.GetCell(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a reference to a cell at the specified coordinates or null if the cell doesn't exist.
member.param: Index of the row.
Index of the column.
member.returns: A reference to the object at the specified coordinates, or null if there is no cell at the specified position.

remarks.para: To populate new sheets, use the indexer instead.
The indexer will automatically create new rows, columns, and cells as needed, and will never return null.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLSheet.Locked
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines if the sheet is locked for editing.

remarks.para: Sheets and styles can be locked. By default, sheets are unlocked and styles are locked. This combination allows users to edit the cells in Excel.
To protect a cell against editing in Excel, both the sheet and the cell style must have the property set to true.
To lock most cells on a sheet and allow editing of only a few cells, lock the sheet, then create an unlocked style and assign it to the cells that should be editable.

member.name: T:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle
member.summary: Contains style elements used to define the appearance of the cells.

remarks.para: Each object may define one or more of the following elements: font, format, background color, background pattern, foreground color, alignment, text direction, and word wrapping.

When displaying a cell, Excel combines the row, column, and cell styles and merges the style elements defined in each one in order to determine how the cell should be displayed. The precedence of the styles is: (1) cell, (2) row, (3) column, (4) default style.
Every belongs to a , and may be assigned to one or more , , and objects through their property.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle.ForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the foreground color for this .

remarks.para: Set the property to Color.Transparent to suppress this style element and use the default foreground color instead (black).

All colors on the are mapped to a palette. This means that if you assign colors to styles, save the book, and then load it back, you probably won't get exactly the same colors used when the book was created. You will get a fairly close approximation though.

member.summary: Gets or sets the format associated with this .

remarks.para: Excel uses formats similar, but not identical to .NET. Refer to the Excel documentation for details on how to create format strings.
You can use the and methods to convert common Excel format strings to and from .NET format strings.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle.WordWrap
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this causes cell contents to wrap.
member.remarks: Cells that do not wrap will spill onto adjacent cells and will be kept on a single line even if they contain line-break characters.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle.Indent
member.summary: Gets or sets the indent cell contents for this .
member.remarks: This property should be set to values between 0 and 255 (between 0 and 15 for Excel 2003 compatible mode), indent calculate as value multiplied by the step (similar TAB value in the text) is equal 2,5 points (180 twips).

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets the context reading direction for this .
member.remarks: This property used only for East Asian versions of MS Excel.

member.name: P:C1.WPF.Excel.XLStyle.Rotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the rotation for this , in degrees.
member.remarks:
This property should be set to values between 0 and 180, or 255, as explained below:
Zero means no rotation.
1-90 means 1 to 90 degrees counter-clockwise (90 causes text to be displayed in the vertical direction going up the cell).
91-180 means 1 to 90 degrees clockwise (180 causes text to be displayed in the vertical direction going down the cell).
255 causes letters to be stacked top to bottom and not rotated. The rotation alays zero if the horizontal alignment is set to Fill or Selection.
